author: _shemnon
content: What about extra data?  such as hard coded pair addresses.

author: _shemnon
content: Cound also be a solution to the triple nested factory

author: lightclient
content: wdym extra data? like data section?

author: _shemnon
content: adding a specific memory segment to the end of the data section, like solidity does for constant final fields set in the constructor.

author: _shemnon
content: A string of memory/value pairs makes more sense in a TX, but if it works off of fixed length and it was something like start address/pair count it would be resilient to bad code.

author: _shemnon
content: _and_ there was no zero compression, just 64 byte sections split into key/value.

author: big_tech_sux
content: my idea about this was to just out-line any basic block whose stack height depends on the entry point

author: _shemnon
content: Not up to date on my complier speak.  What is "out-line"?

author: big_tech_sux
content: it means to take that block of code and turn it into a function

author: _shemnon
content: (outline triggered the part of my brain that says "summarize" not as the converse to in-line)

author: gumb00
content: that's the idea about using CALLF(I) for this, not for relaxing stack validation restriction?

author: big_tech_sux
content: no, i mean the compiler of the EOF code out-lines it transparently

author: big_tech_sux
content: not really, i mean it's like not something the EVM tooling sees

author: big_tech_sux
content: it's more like, if you are compiling some EOF code to native code - you generate a `jmp` vs `call` depending on whether the analysis of the EOF code determines the stack height restriction holds or not

author: gumb00
content: uhm the goal is to statically verify that there're no stack underflows... somehow you'd need to figure out how many inputs/outputs such outlined block has, and that might depend on other blocks... I don't yet fully imagine how it would work, but maybe interesting direction
